body_html:
Protos use a variable width encoding for integers, so there’s really very little to gain from an int32 type for storing data on disk.

@shoyer But input tensor with data type int64 is inefficient, it consumes more computing resource when tf session train or predict model. In many case int32 meets requirements. Many users try to change input data type, they use tf.cast to convert int64 to int32 .
body_text:
Protos use a variable width encoding for integers, so there’s really very little to gain from an int32 type for storing data on disk.

@shoyer But input tensor with data type int64  is inefficient, it consumes more computing resource when tf session train or predict model. In many case int32 meets requirements. Many users try to change input data type, they use tf.cast to convert int64 to int32 .
body:
> Protos use a variable width encoding for integers, so there’s really very little to gain from an int32 type for storing data on disk.

@shoyer But input tensor with data type int64  is inefficient, it consumes more computing resource when tf session train or predict model. In many case int32 meets requirements. Many users try to change input data type, they use tf.cast to convert int64 to int32 .
